awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a microfluidic-based 3D printer for additive manufacturing of biomaterials for fabrication of tissue-on-a-chip models.
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Major Research Instrumentation program supports the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) with the acquisition of a Lab-on-a-Printer (LOP) with RX1 Bioprinting Platform. The instrument will enable accelerated fundamental 3D-bioprinting research at UTEP. The LOP technology is uniquely capable of combining multiple cell types and biomaterial inputs on a single printhead cartridge, enabling the precise deposition of different cells and materials in 3D to recreate and mimic the complex structure of real tissue. The RX1 Bioprinting Platform uses the LOP technology to rapidly and precisely construct functional 3D living tissue, with an advanced material processing capability providing accurate control over patterning of the biological building blocks, rapidly.  At UTEP, the RX1 Bioprinting Platform will be used in several high impact projects including, engineering tissues with blood vessels, the human heart wall, tissues for nerve regeneration and developmental biology, and the application of novel 2D/advanced materials for in-vitro studies. Concurrently, the RX1 Bioprinting Platform will provide sustained and cross-disciplinary studies while contributing to and advancing STEM education and training by providing students access to cutting-edge teaching, research technologies and opportunities.

 
The main objective of the researchers is to employ the Lab-on-a-Printer (LOP)   to utilize hydrogels (synthetic and naturally derived) as scaffolds for bioprinting aimed at tissue-on-a-chip studies. In addition, non-hydrogel type materials such as polymer blends (including Polyurethane, PCL-PLLA), shape memory polymers and nanocomposites with nanowire inclusions will also be targeted. The 3D-printed constructs will include biological neural network development, dose optimization/ minimization of small molecule based therapeutics and enhanced dielectric energy storage and energy harvesting for energy related applications. The LOP technology can easily enable printing of soft structures (such as tissues) which provides needed exploration of biomaterial with advantageous properties than currently possible. The instrument will support multidisciplinary, team-based opportunities involving Engineering faculty at UTEP and faculty from other scientific disciplines and help establish new critical regional collaborations within the state of Texas and neighboring New Mexico. The technology and hands-on use of this printer will be incorporated into existing or new courses with laboratory component, exposing nearly 100 students annually to this technology. It will strengthen outreach to the community, local middle- and high-school students. It will lead to new industry-academic collaborations benefiting both the scientific community at UTEP and industry, nationwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
MRI: ACQUISITION OF A MICROFLUIDIC-BASED 3D PRINTER FOR ADDITIVE MANUFACTURING OF BIOMATERIALS FOR FABRICATION OF TISSUE-ON-A-CHIP MODELS. DMR-MRI #1826268; 09/01/2018 – 08/31/2022; PI: BINATA JODDAR.

Intellectual Merit: The BioAssemblyBot (BAB) supports the PI’s current cardiac tissue engineering research and has helped her establish new critical regional collaborations. In addition to the application of 3D-printed advanced materials for tissue-on-a-chip studies, the BAB will continue to provide sustained and cross-disciplinary studies and support several high-impact projects.

Broader Impacts: The PI has interacted with K-12 students in the El-Paso Del Norte community to advance their understanding of this technology through the well-established UTEP College of Engineering outreach summer program via a workshop titled ‘Eliminating the problem of Organ Scarcity via 3D bioprinting’. The BioAssemblyBot acquired from this prior NSF grant is being used as a platform technology to design and study the engineered tissue constructs for all current and future projects in the PI’s laboratory and is available to the community at large.

Featured Publications from this award:

  • Photocleavable nitroindoline-based crosslinkers. K Michael, C Li, T Boland, HP Del Castillo, B Joddar, AO Sanchez et al. US Patent 11,370,757. 2022
  • 3D Biofabrication of a Cardiac Tissue Construct for Sustained Longevity and Function. M Alonzo, R El Khoury, N Nagiah, V Thakur, M Chattopadhyay, B Joddar. ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, 6. 2022
  • Development and Characterization of Furfuryl-Gelatin Electrospun Scaffolds for Cardiac Tissue Engineering. N Nagiah, R El Khoury, MH Othman, J Akimoto, Y Ito, DA Roberson, B Joddar. ACS omega 7 (16), 13894-13905, 2. 2022
  • 3D bioprinted spheroidal droplets for engineering the heterocellular coupling between cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts. R El Khoury, N Nagiah, JA Mudloff, V Thakur, M Chattopadhyay, B Joddar. Cyborg and Bionic Systems 2021, 6. 2021
  • Cardioprotective Effects Of Glycyrrhizin On Hyperglycemic Cardiac Tissues. M Chattopadhyay, V Thakur, B Joddar. Circulation 144 (Suppl_1), A14396-A14396, 2021
  • A Model for Studying the Biomechanical Effects of Varying Ratios of Collagen Types I and III on Cardiomyocytes. B Roman, SA Kumar, SC Allen, M Delgado, S Moncayo, AM Reyes et al. Cardiovascular engineering and technology 12 (3), 311-324, 1. 2021
  • Bone tissue engineering techniques, advances, and scaffolds for treatment of bone defects. M Alonzo, FA Primo, SA Kumar, JA Mudloff, E Dominguez, G Fregoso et al. Current opinion in biomedical engineering 17, 100248, 45. 2021
  • 3D Bioprinted Spheroidal Droplets for Engineering the Heterocellular Coupling between Cardiomyocytes and Cardiac Fibroblasts. R El Khoury, N Nagiah, JA Mudloff, V Thakur, M Chattopadhyay, B Joddar, 2021.
  • Hydrogel scaffolds with elasticity-mimicking embryonic substrates promote cardiac cellular network formation. M Alonzo, SA Kumar, S Allen, M Delgado, F Alvarez-Primo, L Suggs et al. Progress in biomaterials 9 (3), 125-137, 10. 2020
  • A 3D Bioprinted Human Cardiac Cell Platform to Model the Pathophysiology of Diabetes. B Joddar, S AnilKumar, M Alonzo, V Thakur, M Chattopadhyay. Circulation research 127 (Suppl_1), A465-A465, 3. 2020
  • A comparative study in the printability of a bioink and 3D models across two bioprinting platforms. M Alonzo, E Dominguez, F Alvarez-Primo, A Quinonez, E Munoz et al. Materials letters 264, 127382, 10. 2020
  • Alginate hydrogels with embedded ZnO nanoparticles for wound healing therapy. CM Cleetus, FA Primo, G Fregoso, NL Raveendran, JC Noveron et al. International journal of nanomedicine 15, 5097, 58. 2020
  • Fabrication of surfactant-dispersed HiPco single-walled carbon nanotube-based alginate hydrogel composites as cellular products. F Alvarez-Primo, S Anil Kumar, FS Manciu, B Joddar. International journal of molecular sciences 20 (19), 4802, 12.          2019
  • 3D Bioprinting of cardiac tissue and cardiac stem cell therapy. M Alonzo, S AnilKumar, B Roman, N Tasnim, B Joddar. Translational Research 211, 64-83, 78.        2019
  • A visible light-cross-linkable, fibrin–gelatin-based bioprinted construct with human cardiomyocytes and fibroblasts. S Anil Kumar, M Alonzo, SC Allen, L Abelseth, V Thakur, J Akimoto, Y Ito et al. ACS biomaterials science & engineering 5 (9), 4551-4563, 50. 2019.
  • The applicability of furfuryl‐gelatin as a novel bioink for tissue engineering applications. S AnilKumar, SC Allen, N Tasnim, T Akter, S Park, A Kumar et al. Journal of Biomedical Materials Research Part B: Applied Biomaterials 107,    59. 2019
  • A comparative study of a 3D bioprinted gelatin-based lattice and rectangular-sheet structures. S Anil Kumar, N Tasnim, E Dominguez, S Allen, LJ Suggs, Y Ito, B Joddar. Gels 4 (3), 73
  • Development of an extrusion-based 3D-printing strategy for clustering of human neural progenitor cells. Article reference: HLY_e12250. Heliyon. Corresponding author: Binata Joddar; First author: Ines Bilkic; Article accepted for publication: 1 Dec 2022

 This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content
